programmes.show_description: The RTV Slovenia Symphony Orchestra plays Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony and Falla's Three Cornered Hat. Guitarist Mak Grgic joins for Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez.
Hannah French presents Radio 3's Breakfast show. To get in touch, email 3breakfast@bbc.co.uk.
Tom Service meets horn player Felix Klieser, looks at the problems opera faces with writer Caitlin Vincent, and talks Mike Oldfield's Tubular Bells with arranger Robin A Smith.
Jools is joined by the award-winning film director Nicolas Brown.
Violinist Tasmin Little talks to musicians Kathryn Stott and Sean Bishop who have decided to explore a new life, away from public performance.
Andrew McGregor picks new classical releases with guest reviewers Linton Stephens and Marina Frolova-Walker, who recommends her favourite recording of Weber's opera Der Freischutz.
Alexandre Desplat talks about his BAFTA nominated score to Frankenstein. Plus music from the other 2026 nominees: Max Richter, Ludwig Gorranson, Jonny Greenwood and Jerskin Fendrix.
Jess Gillam swaps favourite music with soprano Ruby Hughes, including tracks by Errollyn Wallen, Sibelius and Dave Okumu.
dipe - George Enescu's masterly retelling of the Oedpius tragedy in a performance from the Bregenz Festival conducted by Hannu Lintu.
Lopa Kothari takes us on a journey across dunes and oases with a live set from Daraa Tribes, recorded at Hootananny, London. Plus, new music from Airelle Besson and Lionel Suarez.
Kate Molleson presents exclusive recordings of Riot Ensemble playing Corie Rose Soumah and Anna Meredith. Plus new releases of the latest in cutting-edge and experimental music.
BBC Proms performance from 2024 that includes Schoenberg's Verklärte Nacht and Mahler's Kindertotenlieder with Alice Coote. Plus Brahms' Third Symphony.
Mark Forrest presents Radio 3's Breakfast show. To get in touch, email 3breakfast@bbc.co.uk.
Join Sarah Walker for three hours of classical masterpieces, perfect for a peaceful start to your day.
Michael Berkeley's guest is the prize-winning designer and artist Asif Khan, who leads an architectural practice working on the transformation of two London landmarks.
To mark the 400th anniversary of John Dowland's death, Sara Mohr-Pietsch traces a path towards John Dowland's famous Lachrimae collection.
Live from the Chapel of Merton College, Oxford on Ash Wednesday, with music by MacMillan, Byrd and Tallis.
Alyn's record box has new releases from Tim Garland & Geoffrey Keezer, Norma Winstone and Alex Wilson plus classic cuts from Duke Ellington, Bill Evans, Lee Morgan and more.
To mark the 400th anniversary of John Dowland's death, Hannah French explores the years the composer spent working in the court of King Christian IV of Denmark.
Be careful what you wish for: some wishes go badly wrong, others bring joy. We look at both kinds of wish, from the Monkey's Paw to Edward Lear's riotous poem about nutcrackers.

programmes.show_name: Between the Ears: Words First meets Sound First
programmes.show_description: Emerging spoken word poets and sound designers collaborate on the theme of 'time'.

programmes.show_name: Sunday Feature: New Generation Thinkers shorts
programmes.show_description: Japan experts Rosina Buckland and Oleg Benesch have included Kabuki Theatre, drums and horns in a show about the influential Japanese warrior class. Chris Harding presents.
The Building a Library recommended recording from yesterday's Record Review.
Kate Molleson and Gillian Moore shine new light on the 'modern' music of the 20th century. This week, Kate explores the experimental sound environments of Alvin Lucier.
A reflective service of night prayer from St Stephen Walbrook, London. With words and music for the end of the day sung by St Martin's Voices.
Sara Mohr-Pietsch presents an adventurous, immersive soundtrack for late-night listening, from classical to contemporary and everything in between.
Elizabeth Alker with music by an exciting new generation of unclassified composers and performers, breaking free of the constraints of practice rooms and concert halls.
